me.alb_i986.selenium.tinafw.domain

Class User

  • java.lang.Object
    • me.alb_i986.selenium.tinafw.domain.User

  • public class User
extends Object
    User encapsulates Browser, and has two main behaviors:
    • openBrowser(): creates an instance of WebDriver, thus opening a real browser
    • doTask(WebTask): performs the given actions against the SUT

    A typical use is as follows: 

     
 new User()
   .openBrowser();
   .doTask(new CompositeWebTask( [..] ));
   .closeBrowser()
 ;
    BTW, this is how tests will look like.

    Typically the navigation will be performed by tasks. Using browseTo(String) instead is not recommended, and it will probably be deprecated/removed.

    A User may have a username and a password. User may be extended in case more information were required (e.g.: a role). Subclasses should just add fields, setters, and getters, and possibly override equals(User).

    • Method Detail

      • openBrowser

        public User openBrowser(SupportedBrowser browserType)
        Open the browser but do not navigate to any page yet. If the browser was already open, does nothing.
        Returns:
        this
        See Also:
        Browser.open(SupportedBrowser)

      • openBrowser

        public User openBrowser()
        Open the browser previously specified with withBrowserType(SupportedBrowser).
        Returns:
        this
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - if the browser type has not been specified, i.e. withBrowserType has not been called
        See Also:
        openBrowser(SupportedBrowser)

      • doTask

        public User doTask(WebTask task)
        Run the given task (or tasks, if it is a CompositeWebTask), starting from the known current page (which is part of the state of this object). Finally update the current page with the one the given task visited last.
        Parameters:
        task -
        Returns:
        this
        See Also:
        WebTask.run(Page)

      • getCurrentPage

        public Page getCurrentPage()
        Returns:
        the page that the last performed task was visiting; or the initial page (which may be null), if no tasks have been performed yet.
